description: } Adds the literal text to the current protocol, after it has been ``||ed''. This command will always be protocolled.
} First calls |@literalbuffered| on literal text. Then, if protocolling is currently switched off, the literal text is passed on to |@invoke|.
Turns on protocolling. All subsequent calls of |@literal| will append their argument to the current protocol.

Turns off protocolling. Subsequent calls of |@literal| directly insert their argument into the current |.pdf| or |.ps|. Note that if the current protocol is not empty when protocolling is switched off, the next call to |@literal| will first flush the current protocol, that is, insert it into the file.
} Stores the current protocol in macro name for later use.
} Sets the current protocol to macro name.
Inserts the text stored in the current protocol into the |.pdf| or |.dvi| file. This does not change the current protocol.
First inserts the current protocol, then sets the current protocol to the empty string.

options} Adds an animation of the attribute of a future object to the current graphic. Attributes are things like the ``fill opacity'' or the transformation matrix or the line width. The options are keys that configure how the attribute changes over time. Using the |entry| key multiple times, you specify which value the chosen attribute should have at different points in time. Unless special keys are used, ``outside'' the specified timeline the animation has no effect: codeexample[ preamble={ani
code} The command works like ||, only instead of options you specify some code whose job is to setup the options.

} This command works like || (indeed, it calls is internally), but returns the result in the macro || rather than ||. Furthermore, the following changes are installed: itemize The postfix operator |s| is added, which has no effect. The postfix operator |ms| is added, which divides a number by 1000, so |2ms| equals 0.002s. The postfix operator |min| is added, which multiplies a number by 60. The postfix operator |h| is added, which multiplies a number by 3600. The infix operator |:| is redefined,

} When this command is used inside a \ scope, the behavior of || changes: Instead of adding an animation to the object and the attribute, the object's attribute is set to value it would have during the animation at time time. Note that when this command is used in a \ scope, no animation is created and no support by the driver is needed (so, it works with pdf). codeexample[preamble={animations}] [make snapshot of=1s, animate = { myself: = { :rotate = { 0s = "0", 2s = "90" }, :color = { 0s = "red

} This command works exactly like || only the ``moment'' that time refers to is conceptually $time + $: When timeline specifies several values for time, this command will select the last value at time, while || will select the first value at time. Similarly, when a timeline ends at time, || will select the last value of the timeline while || will not apply the animation any more: codeexample[preamble={animations}] in {0,1,2,3,4} { :rotate = { 0s = "0", 2s = "90", 2s = "180", 4s = "270" } [draw=b

description: } name bottom left top right tile size code } This command declares a new form-only pattern. The name is a name for later reference. The two parameters lower left and upper right must describe a bounding box that is large enough to encompass the complete tile. The size of a tile is given by tile size, that is, a tile is a rectangle whose lower left corner is the origin and whose upper right corner is given by tile size. This might make you wonder why the second and third parameters are needed. F

} name lower left upper right tile size code } This command works like ||, only the pattern will have an inherent color. To set the color, you should use 's color commands, not the || command, since this fill is not protocolled. codeexample[preamble={patterns}] green stars {}{1cm{1cm}} {1cm{1cm}} { green!50!black {.5cm{.5cm}} {0{4mm}} {144{4mm}} {288{4mm}} {72{4mm}} {216{4mm}} stroke,fill } tikzpicture [pattern=green stars] (0,0) rectangle (3,2); tikzpicture codeexample

color} This command specifies that paths that are filled should be filled with the ``color'' by the pattern name. For an inherently colored pattern, the color parameter is ignored. For form-only patterns, the color parameter specifies the color to be used for the pattern. codeexample[ preamble={patterns stars {}{1cm{1cm}} {1cm{1cm}} { {.5cm{.5cm}} {0{4mm}} {144{4mm}} {288{4mm}} {72{4mm}} {216{4mm}} fill } green stars {}{1cm{1cm}} {1cm{1cm}} { green!50!black {.5cm{.5cm}} {0{4mm}} {144{4mm}} {288{

This command signals that a plot stream starts. The effect of this command is to call the internal command |@plotstreamstart|, which is set by the current plot handler to do whatever needs to be done at the beginning of the plot. It will also reset the meaning of the internal commands like |@plotstreampoint| to the initial setting for the plot handler (what this means will be explained in a moment).

} This command adds a point to the current plot stream. The effect of this command is to call the internal command |@plotstreampoint|, which is also set by the current plot handler. This command should now ``handle'' the point in some sensible way. For example, a line-to command might be issued for the point. When a plot handler is installed, it will setup the internal command |@plotstreampoint| in some way. It is permissible to change the meaning of this internal command during a stream. For in

} An outlier is a point that is ``out of bounds'' in some way. For instance, it might have very large coordinates or the coordinates might just be outside some specified range. Nevertheless, an outlier is still a well-defined point. This command is issued, for instance, by gnuplot when a value is outside the specified range. You can configure how outliers are treated using the following key: key{/pgf/handle outlier points in plots=how (initially jump)} tikz You can set how to one of the followin

This command indicated that the stream contains an ``undefined'' point like a point where some coordinate results for a division by zero. Such a point cannot be plotted, which is why it is not given as a parameter. However, such a point can result in a jump in the plot, depending on the setting of the following key: key{/pgf/handle undefined points in plots=how (initially jump)} tikz You can set how to one of the following values: itemize |ignore| The undefined point will be completely ignored,

This command indicated that in the stream a ``new data set'' starts. So, the stream does not end, but there is a logical break in the data. For example, when a table is read from a file, empty lines are interpreted as indicating new data sets. What happens when a new data set is encountered is governed by the following key: key{/pgf/handle new data sets in plots=how (initially jump)} tikz You can set how to one of the following values: itemize |ignore| The command will be completely ignored, jus
} This command causes |@plotstreamspecial| to be called with text as its parameter. This allows handler-specific information to be passed to the handler. All normal handlers ignore this command.
This command signals that a plot stream ends. It calls |@plotstreamend|, which should now do any necessary ``cleanup''.

} This command will try to open the file filename. If this succeeds, it will convert the file contents into a plot stream as follows: A || is issued. Then, for each empty line a || is produced. Other lines in the file should start with two numbers separated by a space, such as |0.1 1| or |100 -.3|. The numbers may be followed by some text, which will be ignore except if it is exactly ``|u|'' or ``|o|''. For ``|u|'' the point is considered to be undefined and || is called. For ``|o|'' the point i

} This command works like ||, only three numbers are expected on each non-empty line. They are converted into points in the $xyz$-coordinate system. Consider, the following file: codeexample[code only, tikz syntax=false] # more comments 2 -5 1 first entry 2 -.2 2 o 2 -5 2 third entry codeexample It is turned into the following stream: codeexample[code only] {2{-5}{1}} {2{-.2}{2}} {2{-5}{2}} codeexample

sample listpoint} This command will produce coordinates by iterating the variable over all values in sample list, which should be a list in the || syntax. For each value of variable, the point is evaluated and the resulting coordinate is inserted into the plot stream. codeexample[] tikzpicture[x=3.8cm/360] {0,5,...,360}{{sin()+sin(3*)}} stroke tikzpicture codeexample codeexample[] tikzpicture[y=3cm/360] {0,5,...,360}{sin(2*){}{cos(2*)}} stroke tikzpicture codeexample Be warned that if the expres

function} This command will ``try'' to call the gnuplot program to generate the coordinates of the function. In detail, the following happens: This command works with two files: prefix|.gnuplot| and prefix|.table|. If the optional argument prefix is not given, it is set to ||. Let us start with the situation where none of these files exists. Then \ will first generate the file prefix|.gnuplot|. In this file it writes codeexample[code only, tikz syntax=false] set table "#1.table"; set format " co

This handler will issue a || command for each point of the plot, except possibly for the first. What happens with the first point can be specified using the two commands described below. codeexample[] pgfpicture {1cm{0cm}} {2cm{1cm}} {3cm{2cm}} {1cm{2cm}} stroke pgfpicture codeexample

Specifies that the line-to plot handler (and also some other plot handlers) should issue a move-to command for the first point of the plot instead of a line-to. This will start a new part of the current path, which is not always, but often, desirable. This is the default.
Specifies that plot handlers should issue a line-to command for the first point of the plot. codeexample[] pgfpicture {1cm{0cm}} {2cm{1cm}} {3cm{2cm}} {1cm{2cm}} stroke pgfpicture codeexample
This handler works like the line-to plot handler, only the line is closed at the end using ||, resulting in a polygon.
This handler will simply throw away the stream.

} When this handler is installed, each time a plot stream command is called, this command will be appended to macro. Thus, at the end of the stream, macro will contain all the commands that were issued on the stream. You can then install another handler and invoke macro to ``replay'' the stream (possibly many times). codeexample[] pgfpicture {1cm{0cm}} {2cm{1cm}} {3cm{1cm}} {1cm{2cm}} stroke pgfpicture codeexample

argumentsconfiguration} This command creates a new plot handler that can subsequently be called using the macro macro. This macro take the arguments given in arguments, which can be a list like |#1#2| if macro should be invoked with two arguments. Here is a typical example: codeexample[code only] {#1}{...} ... foo ... codeexample The configuration is used to define the behavior of the handler. It is a list of key--value pairs, where the following keys are allowed: itemize |start=|code. The code

description: This macro starts a \ scope inside which the following things happen: enumerate The display layer method |beginGraphDrawingScope| is called, which created a new graph drawing scope inside the graph drawing system and places it on top of an internal stack. From now on, all subsequent interface calls will refer to this scope until || is called, which will pop the scope once more. Inside the \ scope, nodes are not placed immediately. Rather, ||, see Section~section-shapes-deferred-node-positioning,

This macro is used to end a graph drawing scope. It must be given on the same \ grouping level as the corresponding ||. When the macro is called, it triggers a lot of new calls: enumerate The special treatment of newly created boxes is ended. Nodes are once more created normally. The effects of the code that was inserted via the specification hook command also ends (provided it had no global effects). We call |InterfaceToDisplay.runGraphDrawingAlgorithm|. This will cause the algorithm(s) for the

second nodeedge directionedge optionsedge nodes} This command is used to tell the graph drawing engine that there is an edge between first node and second node in your graph. The ``kind'' of connection is indicated by direction, which may be one of the following: itemize |->| indicates a directed edge (also known as an arc) from first node to second node. |--| indicates an undirected edge between first node and second node, |<-| indicates a directed edge from second node to first node, but with

} This command allows you to change the macro that gets called form inside the graph drawing system at the end of the creation of a graph, when the nodes have been positioned. The macro will be called once for each edge with the following parameters: quote macrofirst nodesecond nodedirectionedge optionsedge nodes\\ algorithm-generated optionsbend informationanimations quote The first five parameters are the original values that were passed down to the || command. The algorithm-generated options

This command first starts a new \ scope and then informs the display layer that a new (sub)layout should be started. For each graph there may be a hierarchy of layouts, each of which contains a certain number of vertices and edges. This hierarchy is created through calls to this macros and the corresponding calls of ||. For each graph drawing scope there has to be exactly one main layout that encompasses all nodes and edges and also all sublayouts. Thus, after a graph drawing scope has been open
This command ends the \ scope of the current layout. Once closed, no nodes or edges can be added to a layout.

} This command can only be called when the node named node name has already been created inside the current graph drawing scope. The effect of calling this macro will be that all options currently on the graph drawing system's option stack will be added to the node's option, possibly overwriting the original option settings. Furthermore, the node will become part of all layouts currently on the option stack. This means that you can use this command to add a node to several layouts that are not i

} This command sets up macro as the macro that is called whenever a layout key ``requests'' that a layout and, possibly, a graph drawing scope is opened. When macro is called, it gets two parameters, the begin code and the end code. In addition to whatever setup the macro would like to do, it should execute the begin code at the beginning of a \ scope (the code will open graph drawing and layout scopes) and the end code at the end of the same \ scope. The need for this slightly strange macro ari

parameter} Calls |createEvent| of the graph drawing system's interface class. This creates a new |Event| object on the Lua layer whose |kind| field is set to kind and the |parameters| field to parameter. You must be inside a graph drawing scope to use this command.
} Starts an event group. This just means that an |Event| of kind |begin| is created with the given parameter.
Ends an event group. This is done by adding an event of kind |end| without any parameters to the event string.
} Starts an event group just like ||, but adds a corresponding closing |end| event at the end of the current \ group (using ||).

node optionsnode text} A subgraph node is a node that ``surrounds'' the nodes of a subgraph. The special property of a subgraph node opposed to a normal node is that it is created only after the subgraph has been laid out. However, the difference to a collection like |hyper| is that the node is available immediately as a normal node in the sense that you can connect edges to it. What happens internally is that subgraph nodes get ``registered'' immediately both on the \ level and on the Lua level

remember = \mytime  % \mytime is now 6s

resume   = \mytime  % fork time is still 2s, local time is 3s

description: } Defines || as $1$. This provides greatest accuracy when x is small.
y} Defines || 1.0 if $ x - y < 0.0001$, but 0.0 otherwise. As a side-effect, the global boolean || will be set accordingly.
Defines || as a pseudo-random integer between 1 and $2^{31}-1$. This uses a linear congruency generator, based on ideas of Erich Janka.

minimummaximum} This defines macro as a pseudo-randomly generated integer from the range minimum to maximum (inclusive). codeexample[] pgfpicture in {1,...,50}{ {1}{50} {1}{50} {+ pt{+ pt}}{+2pt} blue!40!white blue!80!black stroke, fill } pgfpicture codeexample
{\{}item-1item-2...{\}}} This creates a list of items with the name list name.
list name} Select an item from a random list list name. The selected item is placed in macro.
} Explicitly sets the seed for the pseudo-random number generator. By default it is set to the value of ||$$||.

numberbase} Defines macro as the result of converting number from base base to base 10. Alphabetic digits can be upper or lower case. { codeexample[] 107f{16} codeexample Note that, as usual in , the braces around an argument can be omitted if the argument is just a single token (a macro name is a single token). codeexample[] 33FC{20} codeexample }
numberbase} Defines macro as the result of converting number from base 10 to base base. Any resulting alphabetic digits are in lower case. codeexample[] 65535{16} codeexample
numberbase} Defines macro as the result of converting number from base 10 to base base. Any resulting alphabetic digits are in upper case. codeexample[] 65535{16} codeexample

numberbase-1base-2} Defines macro as the result of converting number from base base-1 to base base-2. Alphabetic digits in number can be upper or lower case, but any resulting alphabetic digits are in lower case. codeexample[] 11011011{2}{16} codeexample

numberbase-1base-2} Defines macro as the result of converting number from base base-1 to base base-2. Alphabetic digits in number can be upper or lower case, but any resulting alphabetic digits are in upper case. codeexample[] 121212{3}{12} codeexample
} Sets the number of digits in the result of a base conversion to integer. If the result of a conversion has less digits than this number, it is prefixed with zeros. codeexample[] 8 15{2} codeexample

number} This command converts number into a comma-separated list of digits and stores the result in macro. The number is not parsed before processing. codeexample[] 8 tikzpicture[x=0.25cm, y=0.25cm] [count=] in {0, 60, 102, 102, 126, 102, 102, 102, 0}{ {}{2} {} [count=, evaluate={=*50+15;}] in [fill=black!] (, -) rectangle ++(1,1); } tikzpicture codeexample
q} Returns the angle of a line from p to q relative to a line going straight right from p. codeexample[] {1cm{3cm}}{2cm{4cm}} codeexample

description: counter} This macro converts a date in a format to be described in a moment to the Julian day number in the Gregorian calendar. The date should expand to a string of the following form: enumerate calendar-date-format It should start with a number representing the year. Use || for the current year, that is, the year the file is being typeset. The year must be followed by a hyphen. Next should come a number representing the month. Use || for the current month. You can, but need not, use leading ze

year macromonth macroday macro} This command converts a Julian day number to an ISO-date. The Julian day must be a number or \ counter, the year macro, month macro and day macro must be \ macro names. They will be set to numbers representing the year, month, and day of the given Julian day in the Gregorian calendar. The year macro will be assigned the year without leading zeros. Note that this macro will produce year 0 (as opposed to other calendars, where year 0 does not exist). However, if you

week day counter} This command converts a Julian day to a week day by computing the day modulo 7. The week day counter must be a \ counter. It will be set to 0 for a Monday, to 1 for a Tuesday, and so on. |2454115{}| sets || to 2454115{}\ (it was a Sunday).
counter} This command computes the date of Easter Sunday as a Julian date and stores it in counter. |2019{}| sets || to 2019{}, which corresponds to {}{}{} --.

testscodeelse code} pgfcalendarifdate This command is used to execute code based on properties of date. The date must be a date in ISO-format. For this date, the tests are checked (to be detailed later) and if one of the tests succeeds, the code is executed. If none of the tests succeeds, the else code is executed. |2007-02-07{Wednesday}{Is a Wednesday}{Is not a Wednesday}| yields {2007-02-07{Wednesday}{Is a Wednesday}{Is not a Wednesday}}. The tests is a comma-separated list of key--value pairs

} This command expands to a textual representation of the day of week, given by the week day number. Thus, |0| expands to |Monday| if the current language is English and to |Montag| if the current language is German, and so on. See Section~section-calendar-locale for more details on translations. |2| yields {2}.
} This command works similarly to the previous command, only an abbreviated version of the week day is produced. |2| yields {2}.
} This command expands to a textual representation of the month, which is given by the month number. |12| yields {12}.
} As above, only an abbreviated version is produced. |12| yields {12}.

Note that this macro need not be called inside a |{pgfpicture}| environment (even though it typically will be) and you can use it to typeset calendars in normal \ or using packages other than . Basic typesetting process. A calendar is typeset as follows: The start date and end date specify a range of dat

representation} pgfcalendarshorthand This command can be used inside a ||, where it will expand to a representation of the current day, month, year or day of week, depending on whether kind is |d|, |m|, |y| or |w|. The representation can be one of the following: |-|, |=|, |0|, |.|, and |t|. They have the following meanings: itemize The minus sign selects the shortest numerical representation possible (no leading zeros). The equal sign also selects the shortest numerical representation, but a spa

This macro expands to a suggested name for nodes representing days in a calendar. If the prefix is empty, it expands to the empty string, otherwise it expands to the prefix of the calendar, followed by a hyphen, followed by the ISO format version of the date. Thus, when the date |2007-01-01| is typeset in a calendar for the prefix |mycal|, the macro expands to |mycal-2007-01-01|.

description: } This command declares a layer named name for later use. Mainly, this will set up some internal bookkeeping.

} This command tells \ which layers will be used in pictures. They are stacked on top of each other in the order given. The layer |main| should always be part of the list. Here is an example: codeexample[code only] background foreground background,main,foreground codeexample This command should be given either outside of any picture or ``directly inside'' of a picture. Here, the ``directly inside'' means that there should be no further level of \ grouping between || and the matching |pgfpicture|

layer name} The whole environment contents is added to the layer with the name layer name. This environment can be used anywhere inside a picture. Thus, even if it is used inside a |{pgfscope}| or a \ group, the contents will still be added to the ``whole'' picture. Using this environment multiple times inside the same picture will cause the environment contents to accumulate. Note: You can not add anything to the |main| layer using this environment. The only way to add anything to the main laye

text} This command is used to parse the text using the (previously defined) parser named parser name. The text is not contained in curly braces, rather it is all the text that follows. The end of the text is determined implicitly, namely when the final state of the parser has been reached. If you defined a final action for the parser using || it is executed now. The parser works as follows: At any moment, it is in a certain state, initially this state is called |initial|. Then, the first letter
stateaction} With this macro you can define an action for the parser name parser in state if no action was defined for the letter which was encountered.
action} Every parser can call a final action after the state was switched to |final|. This action is executed after everything else, so you can use something that grabs more arguments if you want to.
} This command can be called inside the action code of a parser to cause a state switch to state.

truefalse} Remember that some of the optional argument types set special marks? With || you can test whether arg is such a mark. So if there was no optional argument for the argument types |o| and |d| the true branch will be executed, else the false branch. For the |t| type argument the true branch is executed if the token was encountered.

You can use this as the final macro in an action of || or ||. This has the effect that the contents of || will be parsed next. Without any redefinition the result will be that the last token will be parsed again. You can change the definition of || just before || as well to parse some specific tokens next.
Expands to the current state of the parser.
This is the macro which is let to the following token with ||. You can use it inside an action code.

This macro stores the letter to which || was let. So if you'd use |fooa| this macro would be defined with ||. This definition is done before any action code is executed. There are four special cases: If the next token is of category code 1, 2, 6, or 10, so with standard category codes the tokens |{|, |}|, |#|, and \ (a space), it would be treated differently. In those cases this macro expands to ||, ||, |##|, and \ for the categories 1, 2, 6, and 10, respectively.
} The |pgfparser| module has a few keys you can access through this macro. It is just a shortcut for |/pgfparser/.cd,#1|. The available keys are listed in subsection~sec:parser:keys.

\pgfdeclarefunctionalshading{twospots}
    {\pgfpointorigin}{\pgfpoint{4cm}{4cm}}{}{
  % Save coordinates for later
  2 copy
  % Compute distance from (40bp,45bp), with x doubled
  45 sub dup mul exch
  40 sub dup mul 0.5 mul add sqrt
  % exponential decay
  dup mul neg 1.0005 exch exp 1.0 exch sub
  % Compute distance from (70bp,70bp) from stored coordinate, scaled
  3 1 roll
  70 sub dup mul .5 mul exch
  70 sub dup mul add sqrt
  % Decay
  dup mul neg 1.002 exch exp 1.0 exch sub
  % red component
  1.0 3 1 roll
}
\pgfuseshading{twospots}

\pgfdeclarefunctionalshading[mycol]{sweep}{\pgfpoint{-1cm}{-1cm}}
{\pgfpoint{1cm}{1cm}}{\pgfshadecolortorgb{mycol}{\myrgb}}{
  2 copy        % whirl
  % Calculate "safe" atan of position
  2 copy abs exch abs add 0.0001 ge { atan } { pop } ifelse
  3 1 roll
  dup mul exch
  dup mul add sqrt
  30 mul
  add
  sin
  1 add 2 div
  dup
  \myrgb        % push mycol
  5 4 roll      % multiply all components by calculated value
  mul
  3 1 roll
  3 index
  mul
  3 1 roll
  4 3 roll
  mul
  3 1 roll
}
\colorlet{mycol}{white}%
\pgfuseshading{sweep}%
\colorlet{mycol}{red}%
\pgfuseshading{sweep}

\pgfdeclarefunctionalshading[black]{portabletwospots}{\pgfpointorigin}{\pgfpoint{3.5cm}{3.5cm}}{}{
  2 copy
  45 sub dup mul exch
  40 sub dup mul 0.5 mul add sqrt
  dup mul neg 1.0005 exch exp 1.0 exch sub
  3 1 roll
  70 sub dup mul .5 mul exch
  70 sub dup mul add sqrt
  dup mul neg 1.002 exch exp 1.0 exch sub

  \ifpgfshadingmodelcmyk
    \pgffuncshadingrgbtocmyk

As a side-effect, || will contain the parsed number, either in integer format or as parsed floating point number. description: } This command activates the externalization. It installs commands to replace every -picture. It needs to be called before |document| because it may need to install its separate shipout routine. The optional arguments can be any of the keys described below. Note that the generation/modification of auxiliary files like |.aux|, |.toc| etc.\ is usually suppressed while a single image is externalized (details for || support follow). It is also possible to write ||main job name if the argument is del
Once || has been called, || contains the name of the currently generated output file (which may be |main| or |main-figure0| or |main-figure1| in our example above).
The value of || is one of || or ||, depending on the configuration. In short: if auxiliary file support (|| and ||) is activated, |=| (since that's the base file name of auxiliary files).

} Assigns a common prefix used by all file names. For example, codeexample[code only] figures/ codeexample will prepend |figures/| to every external graphics file name. Please note that || is the only way to assign a prefix in case you want to prepare your document for environments where \ is not installed (see section~section-libs-external-nopgf).

} Sets the file name for the next \ picture or || short command. It will only be used for the next picture. Pictures for which no explicit file name has been set (or the next file name is empty) will get automatically generated file names. Please note that |prefix| will still be prepended to file name. codeexample[code only] article tikz external [prefix=figures/] document trees tikzpicture {root} child {node {left}} child {node {right} child {node {child}} child {node {child}} }; tikzpicture si

} Changes the names of all following figures. It is possible to change |figure name| during the document either using |external/figure name|={name|}| or with this command. A unique counter will be used for each different name, and each counter will start at $0$. The value of |prefix| will be applied after |figure name| has been evaluated. codeexample[code only] article tikz external document tikzpicture {root} child {node {left}} child {node {right} child {node {child}} child {node {child}} }; t
} Appends suffix to the actual value of |figure name|. It is a shortcut for |external/figure name/.add={|suffix|}| (a shortcut which is also supported if \ is not installed, see below).

} Adds a dependency for the next picture which is about to be externalized. If the command is invoked within a picture environment, it adds a dependency for the surrounding picture. Dependencies are written into target file|.dep| in the format target file|.: |file name. The effect is that if file name changes, the external graphics associated with the picture shall be remade. This command uses the contents of to check for graphics. If you encounter difficulties with image extensions, consider re

file name} A variant of || which adds a dependency for an external graphics. The argument external graphics must be the path as it would have been generated by the |external| library, i.e.\ without file extension but including any prefixes.

Allows to disable the complete externalization. While |export next| will still collect the contents of picture environments, this command uninstalls the hooks for the |external| library completely. Thus, nested picture environments or environments where |tikzpicture| is not directly reachable won't produce compilation failures -- although it is not possible to externalize them automatically. The externalization remains disabled until the end of the next \ group (or environment) or until the next
Re-enables a previously running externalization after ||.

false code} This command can be used to check whether an image is currently written to its separate graphics file (if the ``grab'' procedure is running). If so, the true code will be executed. If not, that means if the main document is being typeset normally, the false code will be invoked. This command must be used after ||.
false code} Like ||, but this variant also checks if the next following figure is the one which is about to be written to its separate graphics file.

description: statements\}} This command process a series of statements which can represent assignments, function definitions, conditional evaluation, and iterations. It provides, in effect, a miniature mathematical language to perform basic mathematical operations. Perhaps the most important thing to remember is that every statement should end with a semi-colon. This is likely to be the most common reason why the || command fails. codeexample[preamble={math}] function fibonacci() { if == 0 then { return 0; e

description: image namefilename} Declares an image, but does not paint anything. To draw the image, use ||{image name|}|. The filename may not have an extension. For pdf, the extensions |.pdf|, |.jpg|, and |.png| will automatically tried. For PostScript, the extensions |.eps|, |.epsi|, and |.ps| will be tried. The following options are possible: itemize |height=|{dimension} sets the height of the image. If the width is not specified simultaneously, the aspect ratio of the image is kept. |width=|{dimension} s

existing image name} The existing image name is ``cloned'' and the new image name can now be used whenever the original image is used. This command is useful for creating aliases for alternate extensions and for accessing the last image inserted using ||. |image.!30!white{image.!25!white}|

} Inserts a previously declared image into the normal text. If you wish to use it in a |{pgfpicture}| environment, you must put a || around it. If the macro || expands to some nonempty alternate extension, \ will first try to use the image named image name|.|alternate extension. If this image is not defined, \ will next check whether alternate extension contains a |!| character. If so, everything up to this exclamation mark and including it is deleted from alternate extension and the \ again tri
You should redefine this command to install a different alternate extension. |!25!white|

filename} Declares the image under the name |pgflastimage| and immediately uses it. You can ``save'' the image for later usage by invoking || on |pgflastimage|. codeexample[preamble={xxcolor}] colormixin{25!white} pgfpicture [at=1cm{5cm},left,base] {[interpolate=true,width=1cm,height=1cm]{brave-gnu-world-logo}} [at=1cm{3cm},left,base] {[interpolate=true,width=1cm]{brave-gnu-world-logo}} [at=1cm{1cm},left,base] {[interpolate=true,height=1cm]{brave-gnu-world-logo}} {1cm{5cm}}{1cm{1cm}} {1cm{3cm}}{

mask namefilename} Declares a transparency mask named mask name (called a soft mask in the pdf specification). This mask is read from the file filename. This file should contain a grayscale image that is as large as the actual image. A white pixel in the mask will correspond to ``transparent'', a black pixel to ``solid'', and gray values correspond to intermediate values. The mask must have a single ``color channel''. This means that the mask must be a ``real'' grayscale image, not an rgb-image

description: } Shifts coordinates by point. codeexample[] tikzpicture [help lines] (0,0) grid (3,2); (0,0) -- (2,1) -- (1,0); {1cm{1cm}} [red] (0,0) -- (2,1) -- (1,0); tikzpicture codeexample
} Shifts coordinates by dimension along the $x$-axis. codeexample[] tikzpicture [help lines] (0,0) grid (3,2); (0,0) -- (2,1) -- (1,0); .5cm [red] (0,0) -- (2,1) -- (1,0); tikzpicture codeexample
} Scales coordinates by factor. codeexample[] tikzpicture [help lines] (0,0) grid (3,2); (0,0) -- (2,1) -- (1,0); .75 [red] (0,0) -- (2,1) -- (1,0); tikzpicture codeexample
} Scales coordinates by factor in the $x$-direction. codeexample[] tikzpicture [help lines] (0,0) grid (3,2); (0,0) -- (2,1) -- (1,0); .75 [red] (0,0) -- (2,1) -- (1,0); tikzpicture codeexample

} Slants coordinates by factor in the $x$-direction. Here, a factor of |1| means $45^$. codeexample[] tikzpicture [help lines] (0,0) grid (3,2); (0,0) -- (2,1) -- (1,0); .5 [red] (0,0) -- (2,1) -- (1,0); tikzpicture codeexample
} Slants coordinates by factor in the $y$-direction. codeexample[] tikzpicture [help lines] (0,0) grid (3,2); (0,0) -- (2,1) -- (1,0); -1 [red] (0,0) -- (2,1) -- (1,0); tikzpicture codeexample

} Rotates coordinates counterclockwise by angles given in degrees. codeexample[] tikzpicture [help lines] (0,0) grid (3,2); (0,0) -- (2,1) -- (1,0); 30 [red] (0,0) -- (2,1) -- (1,0); tikzpicture codeexample

bc} This command transforms the coordinate system in such a way that the triangle given by the points a, b and c lies at the coordinates $(0,0)$, $(1pt,0pt)$ and $(0pt,1pt)$. codeexample[] tikzpicture [help lines] (0,0) grid (3,2); {1cm{0cm}} {0cm{2cm}} {3cm{1cm}} (0,0) -- (1pt,0pt) -- (0pt,1pt) -- cycle; tikzpicture codeexample

bcdpoint} Applies the transformation matrix given by $a$, $b$, $c$, and $d$ and the shift point to coordinates (in addition to any previous transformations already in force). codeexample[] tikzpicture [help lines] (0,0) grid (3,2); (0,0) -- (2,1) -- (1,0); 1{1}{0}{1}{.25cm{.25cm}} [red] (0,0) -- (2,1) -- (1,0); tikzpicture codeexample

end} Shifts coordinates to the end of the line going from start to end with the correct rotation. codeexample[] tikzpicture [help lines] (0,0) grid (3,2); (0,0) -- (3,1); {3cm{1cm}} tip tikzpicture codeexample

startend} Shifts coordinates by a specific point on a line at a specific time. The point by which the coordinate is shifted is calculated by calling ||, see Section~section-pointsattime. In addition to shifting the coordinate, a rotation may also be applied. Whether this is the case depends on whether the \ if || is set to true or not. codeexample[] tikzpicture [help lines] (0,0) grid (3,2); (0,0) -- (2,1); .25{}{2cm{1cm}} Hi! tikzpicture codeexample codeexample[] tikzpicture [help lines] (0,0)

startfirst supportsecond supportend} Shifts coordinates by a specific point on a curve at a specific time, see Section~section-pointsattime once more. As for the line-at-time transformation command, || decides whether an additional rotation should be applied. Again, the value of || is also considered. codeexample[] tikzpicture [help lines] (0,0) grid (3,2); (0,0) .. controls (0,2) and (1,2) .. (2,1); .25{} {0cm{2cm}}{1cm{2cm}}{2cm{1cm}} Hi! tikzpicture codeexample codeexample[] tikzpicture [help

center0-degree axis90-degree axisstart angleend angle } Shifts coordinates by a specific point on an arc at a specific time, see Section~section-pointsattime once more. As for the previous commands, || decides whether an additional rotation should be applied and || is also considered. codeexample[] tikzpicture [help lines] (0,0) grid (3,2); {2cm{1cm}} 0{60}{2cm{0cm}}{0cm{1cm}} stroke .25 {0cm{1cm}} {2cm{0cm}}{0cm{1cm}} {0}{60} Hi! tikzpicture codeexample The value of || is also taken into accoun

Resets the coordinate transformation matrix to the identity matrix. Thus, once this command is given no transformations are applied till the end of the scope. codeexample[] tikzpicture [help lines] (0,0) grid (3,2); 30 (0,0) -- (2,1) -- (1,0); [red] (0,0) -- (2,1) -- (1,0); tikzpicture codeexample

This command sets the $a$, $b$, $c$, and $d$ part of the coordinate transformation matrix to $a=1$, $b=0$, $c=0$, and $d=1$. However, the current shifting of the matrix is not modified. The effect of this command is that any rotation/scaling/slanting is undone in the current \ group, but the origin is not ``moved back''. This command is mostly useful directly before a || command to ensure that the text is not scaled or rotated. codeexample[] tikzpicture [help lines] (0,0) grid (3,2); 2 30 1cm {r

Replaces the coordinate transformation matrix by a coordinate transformation matrix that ``exactly undoes the original transformation''. For example, if the original transformation was ``scale by 2 and then shift right by 1cm'' the new one is ``shift left by 1cm and then scale by $1/2$''. This command will produce an error if the determinant of the matrix is too small, that is, if the matrix is near-singular. codeexample[] tikzpicture [help lines] (0,0) grid (3,2); 30 (0,0) -- (2,1) -- (1,0); [r
} This command will (locally) define macro to a representation of the current coordinate transformation matrix. This matrix can later on be reinstalled using ||.
} Reinstalls a coordinate transformation matrix that was previously saved using ||.

macro for bmacro for cmacro for dmacro for shift xmacro for shift y } This command is similar to || except that it stores the current coordinate transformation matrix in a set of six macros. The matrix can later on be reinstalled using ||. Furthermore, all these macros (or just a few of them) can be used as arguments for ||.

bcdshiftxshifty} Reinstalls a coordinate transformation matrix that was previously saved using the storage command ||. This command can also be used to replace any previously existing coordinate transformation matrix (it is thus equivalent to || followed by ||).

} Applies current transformation matrix to point $(x,y)$ and returns a transformed point $(ax+cy+s,bx+dy+t)$. Normally, this is done automatically by commands like || or ||, but sometimes you may wish to access a transformed point yourself.

This command computes ``adjustments'' for the current transformation matrix so that even when you install a transformation matrix that scales everything by a certain factor, you can still draw something of ``an absolute size''. Suppose for instance that you install a transformation matrix that scales everything by a factor of 4 and you now wish to draw a horizontal line of length 1cm. Then, if you do not reset the transformation matrix, you can draw a line of logical length 2.5mm, which will the

This command concatenates the canvas transformation matrix with the current coordinate transformation matrix. Afterward, the coordinate transformation matrix is reset. The effect of this command is to ``synchronize'' the coordinate transformation matrix and the canvas transformation matrix. All transformations that were previously applied by the coordinate transformations matrix are now applied by the canvas transformation matrix. codeexample[] tikzpicture [help lines] (0,0) grid (3,2); 1pt 5 (0

} This command concatenates the canvas transformation matrix with the coordinate transformation specified by transformation code. codeexample[] tikzpicture [help lines] (0,0) grid (3,2); 1pt {5} (0,0) -- (0.4,.2); tikzpicture codeexample

code} This command creates a local |{pgfscope}|. Inside this scope, || is first called with the argument transformation code, then the code is inserted. codeexample[] tikzpicture [help lines] (0,0) grid (3,2); 1pt {5} { (0,0) -- (0.4,.2);} {-1cm}{ (0,0) -- (0.4,.2);} tikzpicture codeexample

} This command adds the transformation code to the list of non-linear transformations currently in force. Thus, similar to linear coordinate transformations, each additional call to this function adds another transformation to the current \ scope and the effect ends at the end of the current scope. In practice, however, you typically will not have more than one active nonlinear transformation. The job of the transformation code is to map a point~$p$ given in the registers |@x| and |@y| to a new

} Works like ||, but also applies the current nonlinear transformation; that is, it first applies the current linear transformation and then the current nonlinear transformations. Note that, just like ||, you normally do not call this function directly since it is called internally by the path drawing commands.

(initially 5pt)} Whenever in a to-be-drawn curve the $L^$-distance (maximum of the distances in $x$- and $y$-directions) between the start of a curve and its first control point or between the first and second control points or between the second control point and the end is more than distance, the curve gets split in the middle (more precisely, at time $t= 0.5$) and we draw the two parts individually (for them, splitting may occur again, if the curve is still too long). codeexample[preamble={no

This command will do two things: enumerate It clears the nonlinear transformations for the rest of the current \ scope, so only linear transformations apply. However, before removing the nonlinear transformations, the linear transformation matrix is modified so that it mimics the effect the nonlinear transformation had at the origin. That is, after you call this command, drawing something near the origin will look almost the same as if you had not called it. enumerate codeexample[preamble={nonli

This command works like the normal approximation command, but it will only approximate how the origin gets translated, it will not approximate the rotation, skewing, or scaling that is involved. This is useful for drawing text at the right position, but without ``mutilating'' the text. codeexample[preamble={nonlineartransformations}] tikzpicture [help lines] (0,0) grid (3,2); (0pt,0mm) grid [xstep=10pt, ystep=5mm] (90pt, 20mm); scope[shift={(45pt,20mm)}] [red] (-10pt,-10pt) -- (10pt,10pt); [red]

first supportsecond supportend} Prior to using any other command from this library, you first call this function to ``install'' a Bzier curve to which the commands will refer. This curve will be local to the current \ scope and you can install only one curve at a time. The main job of this command is to store the passed points internally and to build a lookup table for distance-to-time conversions, see the next command. codeexample[code only] {} {1cm{1cm}} {2cm{1cm}} {3cm{0cm}} codeexample

} This command does a ``distance-to-time-conversion'': It tries to compute a time $t$, returned in |@x|, that corresponds to travelling distance along the curve that has last been installed using the command ||. The distance-to-time-conversion uses the precomputations done by that command. Note that several compromises had to be made between speed and accuracy: itemize The conversion will be best near the start of the curve. The more ``degenerate'' the curve, the worse the results. itemize

offset} This command computes the following point: Consider the curve last installed using the command ||. We travel along this curve by distance, arriving at a point $p$. Then, we turn by $90^$ and travel by offset units ``always from the curve'', arriving at a point $q$. This point $q$ will now be returned in |@x| and |@y|; furthermore, the transformed local coordinate system at point $q$ will also be returned |@xa| and the other registers, see || for details. codeexample[ preamble={nonlineart

y} This command is similar to the previous version, but the transformation is different: The idea is that a line form $(0,0)$ to $(x,0)$ gets transformed to the curve from the start of the curve to a point at distance $x$ along the curve. This is identical to what the ``orthogonal'' transformation above also does. The difference is that a line from $(0,0)$ to $(0,y)$ gets still transformed to an initial segment of the curve of a length of $y$, but now rotated by $90^$. In general, the point $p =

transformation code} This environment first surrounds the environment contents by a |{pgfscope}|. Then it calls || with the argument transformation code. codeexample[] tikzpicture [help lines] (0,0) grid (3,2); 1pt pgflowlevelscope{5} (0,0) -- (0.4,.2); pgflowlevelscope pgflowlevelscope{-1cm} (0,0) -- (0.4,.2); pgflowlevelscope tikzpicture codeexample

$ll_1$$ur_1$$ll_2$$ur_2$meet or slice} Inside the viewbox scope, the source rectangle (with the two \ points $ll_1$ and $ur_1$ as corners) will be translated and scaled so that it becomes centered on the target rectangle (with the corners $ll_2$ and $ur_2$) and will, for |meet| as last parameter, be as large as possible so that it fits inside the target and, for |slice|, be as small as possible so that it encompasses the target. codeexample[] { [red, very thick] (0,0) rectangle (20mm,20mm); pgfv

\makeatletter
\def\polartransformation{
  % \pgf@x will contain the radius
  % \pgf@y will contain the distance
  \pgfmathsincos@{\pgf@sys@tonumber\pgf@x}%
  % pgfmathresultx is now the cosine of radius and
  % pgfmathresulty is the sine of radius
  \pgf@x=\pgfmathresultx\pgf@y%
  \pgf@y=\pgfmathresulty\pgf@y%
}
\makeatother

\def\polartransformation{%
  % \pgf@x will contain the radius
  % \pgf@y will contain the distance
  \pgfmathsincos@{\pgf@sys@tonumber\pgf@x}%
  % pgfmathresultx is now the cosine of radius and
  % pgfmathresulty is the sine of radius
  \pgf@x=\pgfmathresultx\pgf@y%
  \pgf@y=\pgfmathresulty\pgf@y%
}

description: } Defines a new profiler entry named name. This updates a set of internal registers used to track the profiler entry. The name can be arbitrary, it doesn't need to be related to any \ macro. The actual job of counting seconds is accomplished using ||name followed eventually by the command ||name. It doesn't hurt if || is called multiple times with the same name.

macroarguments} Defines a new profiler entry which will measure the time spent in macro. This calls || and replaces the current definition of macro with a new one. If profiler entry name has been provided, this defines the argument for ||. It is allowed to use the same name for multiple commands; in this case, they are treated as if it where the same command. If the optional argument is not used, the profiler entry will be called `' (macro without backslash) where || is predefined to be |<CS>|.

macroargument patterninvocation pattern} A variant of || which can be used with arbitrary argument patterns. Example: codeexample[code only] #1#2#3{ ... } {#1#2#3}{{#1}#2#3} codeexample Note that || is a special case of ||: codeexample[code only] #1#2{ ... } 2 {#1#2}{{#1}{#2}} codeexample Thus, argument pattern is a copy-paste from the definition of your command. The invocation pattern is used by the |profiler| library to invoke the original command, so it is closely related to argument pattern,

} Enables verbose output for every invocation of profiler entry name. This is only available for profiler entries for commands (those created by || for example). It will also show all given arguments.

} A variant of || which will expand all arguments for profiler entry name before showing them. The invocation as such is not affected by this expansion. This expansion (with ||) might yield unrecoverable errors for some commands. Handle with care.

environment name} Defines a new profiler entry which measures time spent in the environment environment name. This calls || and handles the begin/end of the environment automatically. The argument for || is profiler entry name, or, if this optional argument is not used, it is ` name' where || is predefined as |<ENV>|. Again, it is permitted to use the same profiler entry name multiple times to merge different commands into one output section.

} Starts (or resumes) timing of profiler entry name. The argument must have been declared in the preamble using ||. Nested calls of || with the same argument will be ignored. The invocation of this command doesn't change the environment: it doesn't introduce any \ groups nor does it modify the token list.
} Stops (or interrupts) timing of profiler entry name. This command finishes a preceding call to ||.

For , this command is installed automatically in |document|. It stops all running timings, evaluates them and returns the result into the logfile. Furthermore, it generates a text table called |.profiler.|YYYY|-|MM|-|DD|_|HH|h_|MM|m.dat| with the same information. Note that the |profiler| library predefines two profiler entries, namely |main job| which counts time from the beginning of the document until || and |preamble| which counts time from the beginning of the document until |document|.

(initially main job)} Sets the profiler entry whose total time will be used to compute all other relative times. Thus, profiler entry name will use $100\ total time per definition, all other relative times are relative to this one.
true codefalse code} Invokes true code if profiler entry name is currently running and false code otherwise.

description: This handler will issue a || command for each point of the plot, except possibly for the first. As for the line-to handler, what happens with the first point can be specified using || or ||. Obviously, the || command needs, in addition to the points on the path, some control points. These are generated automatically using a somewhat ``dumb'' algorithm: Suppose you have three points $x$, $y$, and $z$ on the curve such that $y$ is between $x$ and $z$: codeexample[] tikzpicture [gray] (0,0) node {x

} Sets the factor used by the curve plot handlers to determine the distance of the control points from the points they control. The higher the curvature of the curve points, the higher this value should be. A value of $1$ will cause four points at quarter positions of a circle to be connected using a circle. The default is $0.5$. codeexample[] tikzpicture [gray] (0,0) node {x} (1,1) node {y} (2,.5) node {z}; 0.75 {0cm{0cm}} {1cm{1cm}} {2cm{0.5cm}} stroke tikzpicture codeexample

This handler works like the curve-to plot handler, only it will add a new part to the current path that is a closed curve through the plot points. codeexample[] tikzpicture [gray] (0,0) node {x} (1,1) node {y} (2,.5) node {z}; {0cm{0cm}} {1cm{1cm}} {2cm{0.5cm}} stroke tikzpicture codeexample

This handler works like the line-to plot handler, only it will produce a connected, piecewise constant path to connect the points. codeexample[] tikzpicture [gray] (0,0) node {x} (1,1) node {y} (2,.5) node {z}; {0cm{0cm}} {1cm{1cm}} {2cm{0.5cm}} stroke tikzpicture codeexample

A variant of || which places its mark on the right line ends. codeexample[] tikzpicture [gray] (0,0) node {x} (1,1) node {y} (2,.5) node {z}; {0cm{0cm}} {1cm{1cm}} {2cm{0.5cm}} stroke tikzpicture codeexample

A variant of || which places its mark on the center of the line. codeexample[] tikzpicture [gray] (0,0) node {x} (1,1) node {y} (2,.5) node {z}; {0cm{0cm}} {1cm{1cm}} {2cm{0.5cm}} stroke tikzpicture codeexample The plot handler always connects two data points by a horizontal line starting from the previous data points, followed by a vertical line in the middle between the two data points, followed by a horizontal line between the middle and the current data point. This results in a symmetric con

This handler works like the line-to plot handler, only it will produce a non-connected, piecewise constant path to connect the points. If there are any plot marks, they will be placed on the left open pieces. codeexample[] tikzpicture [gray] (0,0) node {x} (1,1) node {y} (2,.5) node {z}; {0cm{0cm}} {1cm{1cm}} {2cm{0.5cm}} stroke tikzpicture codeexample

This handler works like the line-to plot handler, only it will produce a non-connected, piecewise constant path to connect the points. If there are any plot marks, they will be placed on the right open pieces. codeexample[] tikzpicture [gray] (0,0) node {x} (1,1) node {y} (2,.5) node {z}; {0cm{0cm}} {1cm{1cm}} {2cm{0.5cm}} stroke tikzpicture codeexample

This handler works like the ||, but it will produce a non-connected, piecewise constant path to connect the points. If there are any plot marks, they will be placed in the center of the horizontal line segment.. codeexample[] tikzpicture [gray] (0,0) node {x} (1,1) node {y} (2,.5) node {z}; {0cm{0cm}} {1cm{1cm}} {2cm{0.5cm}} stroke tikzpicture codeexample See || for details.

This handler converts each point in the plot stream into a line from the $y$-axis to the point's coordinate, resulting in a ``horizontal comb''. codeexample[] tikzpicture [gray] (0,0) node {x} (1,1) node {y} (2,.5) node {z}; {0cm{0cm}} {1cm{1cm}} {2cm{0.5cm}} stroke tikzpicture codeexample

This handler converts each point in the plot stream into a line from the $x$-axis to the point's coordinate, resulting in a ``vertical comb''. This handler is useful for creating ``bar diagrams''. codeexample[] tikzpicture [gray] (0,0) node {x} (1,1) node {y} (2,.5) node {z}; {0cm{0cm}} {1cm{1cm}} {2cm{0.5cm}} stroke tikzpicture codeexample

This handler converts each point in the plot stream into a line from the origin to the point's coordinate. codeexample[] tikzpicture [gray] (0,0) node {x} (1,1) node {y} (2,.5) node {z}; {0cm{0cm}} {1cm{1cm}} {2cm{0.5cm}} stroke tikzpicture codeexample
} This zero level stream always returns dimension instead of $x=0$pt. It is used for |xcomb| and |xbar|.
} This zero level stream always returns dimension instead of $y=0$pt. It is used for |ycomb| and |ybar|.

This handler converts each point in the plot stream into a rectangle from the $x$-axis to the point's coordinate. The rectangle is placed centered at the $x$-axis. codeexample[] tikzpicture [gray] (0,0) node {x} (1,1) node {y} (2,.5) node {z}; {0cm{0cm}} {1cm{1cm}} {2cm{0.5cm}} stroke tikzpicture codeexample

This handler converts each point in the plot stream into a rectangle from the $y$-axis to the point's coordinate. The rectangle is placed centered at the $y$-axis. codeexample[] tikzpicture [gray] (0,0) node {x} (1,1) node {y} (2,.5) node {z}; {0cm{0cm}} {1cm{1cm}} {2cm{0.5cm}} stroke tikzpicture codeexample
Expands to the value of |/pgf/bar width|.

This handler is a variant of || which works with intervals instead of points. Bars are drawn between successive input coordinates and the width is determined relatively to the interval length. codeexample[] tikzpicture [gray] (0,2) node {$x_1$} (1,1) node {$x_2$} (2,.5) node {$x_3$} (4,0.7) node {$x_4$}; {0cm{2cm}} {1cm{1cm}} {2cm{0.5cm}} {4cm{0.7cm}} stroke tikzpicture codeexample In more detail, if $(x_i,y_i)$ and $(x_{i+1},y_{i+1})$ denote successive input coordinates, the bar will be placed
As ||, this handler provides bar plots with relative bar sizes and offsets, one bar for each $y$~coordinate interval.

This handler will connect the points of the plots by straight line segments. However, at the start and the end of the lines there will be a small gap, given by the following key: key{/pgf/gap around stream point=dimension (initially 1.5pt)} The dimension by which the lines between consecutive stream points are shortened at the beginning and end. key codeexample[] tikzpicture {0cm{0cm}} {1cm{1cm}} {2cm{0.5cm}} stroke tikzpicture codeexample
Works like ||, but the last point is connected to the first in the same fashion: codeexample[] tikzpicture {0cm{0cm}} {1cm{1cm}} {2cm{0.5cm}} stroke tikzpicture codeexample

} This command will execute the mark code for some points of the plot, but each time the coordinate transformation matrix will be set up such that the origin is at the position of the point to be plotted. This way, if the mark code draws a little circle around the origin, little circles will be drawn at some point of the plot. By default, a mark is drawn at all points of the plot. However, two parameters $r$ and $p$ influence this. First, only every $r$th mark is drawn. Second, the first mark dr
} Sets the $r$ parameter to repeat, that is, only every $r$th mark will be drawn.
} Sets the $p$ parameter to phase, that is, the first mark to be drawn is the $p$th, followed by the $(p+r)$th, then the $(p+2r)$th, and so on.

index list} This command works similar to the previous one. However, marks will only be placed at those indices in the given index list. The syntax for the list is the same as for the || statement. For example, if you provide the list |1,3,...,25|, a mark will be placed only at every second point. Similarly, |1,2,4,8,16,32| yields marks only at those points that are powers of two. codeexample[] tikzpicture [gray] (0,0) node {x} (1,1) node {y} (2,.5) node {z}; {{4pt}stroke} {1,3} {0cm{0cm}} {1cm{

} Draws the given plot mark name at the origin. The plot mark name must have been previously declared using ||. codeexample[] tikzpicture [gray] (0,0) node {x} (1,1) node {y} (2,.5) node {z}; {pentagon} {0cm{0cm}} {1cm{1cm}} {2cm{0.5cm}} stroke tikzpicture codeexample

code} Declares a plot mark for later used with the || command. codeexample[] my plot mark {{0cm{1ex}}{1ex}} tikzpicture [gray] (0,0) node {x} (1,1) node {y} (2,.5) node {z}; {my plot mark} {0cm{0cm}} {1cm{1cm}} {2cm{0.5cm}} stroke tikzpicture codeexample

} This command sets the \ dimension || to dimension. This dimension is a ``recommendation'' for plot mark code at which size the plot mark should be drawn; plot mark code may choose to ignore this dimension altogether. For circles, dimension should be the radius, for other shapes it should be about half the width/height. The predefined plot marks all take this dimension into account. codeexample[] tikzpicture [gray] (0,0) node {x} (1,1) node {y} (2,.5) node {z}; 1ex {*} {0cm{0cm}} {1cm{1cm}} {2c

} This command indicates that everything up to the next call of || is part of a graphic that should be placed in a file named file name prefix|.|suffix, where the suffix depends on your backend driver. Typically, suffix will be |dvi| or |pdf|. Here is a typical example of how this command is used: codeexample[code only] ... As we see in Figure~fig1, the world is flat. figure graphic-of-flat-world tikzpicture (0,0) circle (1cm); tikzpicture The flat world. fig1 figure codeexample Each graphic to
This command just marks the end of the graphic that should be externalized.

description: } This command will store the current soft path in macro name.

} This command will set the current soft path to be the path stored in macro name. This macro should store a path that has previously been extracted using the |@getcurrentpath| command and has possibly been modified subsequently.

This command will turn the current soft path in a ``hard'' path. To do so, it iterates over the soft path and calls an appropriate |@xxxx| command for each element of the path. Note that the current soft path is not changed by this command. Thus, in order to start a new soft path after the old one has been invoked and is no longer needed, you need to set the current soft path to be empty. This may seem strange, but it is often useful to immediately use the last soft path again.
This command will invoke the current soft path and then set it to be empty.

y} This command appends a ``move-to'' segment to the current soft path. The coordinates x and y are given as normal \ dimensions. One way to draw a line: codeexample[code only] @moveto{0pt}{0pt} @lineto{10pt}{10pt} @flushcurrentpath @stroke codeexample
y} Appends a ``line-to'' segment to the current soft path.
bcdxy} Appends a ``curve-to'' segment to the current soft path with controls $(a,b)$ and $(c,d)$.
lower left ywidthheight} Appends a rectangle segment to the current soft path.
Appends a ``close-path'' segment to the current soft path.

description: y} This command does the same as ||, but x and y must be simple dimensions like |1pt| or |1cm|. Things like |2ex| or |2cm+1pt| are not allowed.
$s_y$} This command does the same as ||, but $s_x$ and $s_y$ must be simple numbers without unit, like |1.234| or |5.0|. Mathematical expressions or units are not allowed.
$s_y$$s_z$} As ||, but for three-dimensional coordinates. Any argument needs to be a number without unit.
coordinate} As ||, but factor must be a simple number without unit, as for the other ``quick'' commands.

y dimension} Either starts a path or starts a new part of a path at the coordinate $(x dimension,y dimension)$. The coordinate is not transformed by the current coordinate transformation matrix. However, any low-level transformations apply. codeexample[] tikzpicture [help lines] (0,0) grid (3,2); 1cm 0pt{0pt} 1cm{1cm} {2cm{0cm}} stroke tikzpicture codeexample
y dimension} The quick version of the line-to operation.

$s^1_y$$s^2_x$$s^2_y$$t_x$$t_y$} The quick version of the curve-to operation. The first support point is $(s^1_x,s^1_y)$, the second support point is $(s^2_x,s^2_y)$, and the target is $(t_x,t_y)$. codeexample[] tikzpicture [help lines] (0,0) grid (3,2); 0pt{0pt} 1cm{1cm}{2cm}{1cm}{3cm}{0cm} stroke tikzpicture codeexample

} Adds a radius around the origin of the given radius. This command is orders of magnitude faster than |{|radius|}|. codeexample[] examplefill{yellow!80!black} tikzpicture [help lines] (0,0) grid (1,1); 10pt examplefill stroke,fill tikzpicture codeexample
Strokes the path without further ado. No arrows are drawn, no corners are arced. codeexample[] pgfpicture 5pt pgfpicture codeexample
Fills the path without further ado.
Fills and then strokes the path without further ado.
Clips all subsequent drawings against the current path. The path is not processed.
} This command inserts a \ box into a |{pgfpicture}| by ``escaping'' to , inserting the box number box number at the origin, and then returning to the typesetting the picture.

} This command works similarly to the || command. However, before inserting the text in box number, the current coordinate transformation matrix is applied to the current canvas transformation matrix (is it ``synced'' with this matrix, hence the name). Thus, this command basically has the same effect as if you first called || followed by ||. However, this command will use || and || commands for the ``translational part'' of the coordinate transformation matrix, instead of adding the translationa

description: options} Installs the specified layout with the given options. The predefined layouts and their permissible options are explained below. If this function is called multiple times, only the last call ``wins''. You can thereby overwrite any previous settings. In particular, layouts do not accumulate. |resize to[a4paper]|

before actionsafter actions} This command predefines a layout that can later be installed using the || command. When ||layoutoptions is called, the following happens: First, the before actions are executed. They can be used, for example, to set up default values for keys. Next, |pgfpagesuselayoutoption|options is executed. Finally, the after actions are executed. Here is an example: codeexample[code only] resize to { 0pt } { { logical pages=1, physical height=, physical width= } 1 { resized widt

} This command sets the characteristics of the ``physical'' page. For example, it is used to specify how many logical pages there are and how many logical pages must be accumulated before a physical page is shipped out. How each individual logical page is typeset is specified using the command ||, described later. A layout for putting two portrait pages on a single landscape page: codeexample[code only] { logical pages=2, physical height=, physical width=, } 1 { resized width=.5, resized height=

options} This command is used to specify where the logical page number logical page number will be placed on the physical page. In addition, this command can be used to install additional ``code'' to be executed when this page is put on the physical page. The number logical page number should be between 1 and logical pages, which has previously been installed using the || command. The following options may be given: itemize |center=|{pgf point} specifies the center of the logical page inside the

box} This command sets to logical page number to box. The box should be the code of a \ box command. This command does not influence the counter current logical page and does not cause a physical shipout. codeexample[code only] 0Hi! codeexample This command can be used to set the contents of logical pages that are normally not filled.

} When the current \ page has been typeset, it will be become the given logical page number. This command ``interrupts'' the normal order of logical pages, that is, it behaves like the previous command and does not update the current logical page counter. codeexample[code only] two screens with optional second ... Text for main page. 2 Text that goes to second page Text for main page. codeexample

description: } Sets the opacity of stroking operations. The value should be a number between |0| and |1|, where |1| means ``fully opaque'' and |0| means ``fully transparent''. A value like |0.5| will cause paths to be stroked in a semitransparent way. codeexample[] pgfpicture 5mm red {0cm{0cm}}{10mm} stroke black 0.5 {1cm{0cm}}{10mm} stroke pgfpicture codeexample

} Sets the opacity of filling operations. As for stroking, the value should be a number between |0| and~|1|. The ``filling transparency'' will also be used for text and images. codeexample[] tikzpicture 0.5 [red] (90:1cm) circle (11mm); [green] (210:1cm) circle (11mm); [blue] (-30:1cm) circle (11mm); tikzpicture codeexample

} Sets the blend mode to one of the values described in Section~section-blend-modes. As described there, blend modes are an advanced feature of pdf and not always rendered correctly. codeexample[] [transparency group] { screen [red!90!black] ( 90:.6) circle (1); [green!80!black] (210:.6) circle (1); [blue!90!black] (330:.6) circle (1); } codeexample

contents} This command declares a fading named name for later use. The ``picture'' on which the fading is based is given by the contents. The contents are normally typeset in a \ box. The resulting box is then used as the ``picture''. In particular, inside the contents you must explicitly open a |{pgfpicture}| environment if you wish to use \ commands. Let's start with an easy example. Our first fading picture is just some text: codeexample[] fading1{white{TikZ}} tikzpicture [black!20] (0,0) rec

transformations} This command sets the graphic state parameter ``fading'' to a previously defined fading name. This graphic state works like other graphic states, that is, is persists till the end of the current scope or until a different transparency setting is chosen. When the fading is installed, it will be centered on the origin with its natural size. Anything outside the fading picture's original bounding box will be transparent and, thus, the fading effectively clips against this bounding

transformations} This command works like ||, but the fading is scaled and transformed according to the following rules: enumerate If the current path is empty, the command has the same effect as ||. Otherwise it is assumed that the fading has a size of 100bp times 100bp. The fading is resized and shifted (using appropriate transformations) such that the position $(25bp,25bp)$ lies at the lower-left corner of the current path and the position $(75bp,75bp)$ lies at the upper-right corner of the cu

transformations} This command works like ||, only the current path is enlarged by the line width in both $x$- and $y$-direction. This is exactly the enlargement necessary to compensate for the fact that if the current path will be stroked, this much needs to be added around the path's bounding box to actually contain the path. codeexample[preamble={shading{100bp} { color(0pt)=(transparent!0); color(25bp)=(transparent!0); color(75bp)=(transparent!100); color(100bp)=(transparent!100)} fading{shadi

{options}} This environment should only be used inside a |{pgfpicture}|. It has the following effect: enumerate The environment contents are stroked/filled ``ignoring any outside transparency''. This means, all previous transparency settings are ignored (you can still set transparency inside the group, but never mind). This means that if in the environment contents you stroke a pixel three times in black, it is just black. Stroking it white afterwards yields a white pixel, and so on. When the gr
Called at the beginning of a |{pgfpicture}|. This command should ``set up things''. Most drivers will need to implement this command.
Called at the end of a |{pgfpicture}|. Most drivers will need to implement this command.

} Called after a |{pgfpicture}| has been typeset. The picture will have been put in box box. This command should insert the box into the normal text. The box box will still be a ``raw'' box that contains only the ||'s that make up the description of the picture. The job of this command is to resize and shift box according to the baseline shift and the size of the box. This command has a default implementation and need not be implemented by a driver file.

This version of the |@beginpicture| picture command can be used for pictures that are guaranteed not to contain any escaped boxes (see below). In this case, a driver might provide a more compact version of the command. This command has a default implementation and need not be implemented by a driver file.
Called at the end of a ``pure'' |{pgfpicture}|. This command has a default implementation and need not be implemented by a driver file.
} Called to insert a (horizontal) TeX box inside a |{pgfpicture}|. Most drivers will need to (re-)implement this command.

} Called to insert a (horizontal) TeX box inside a |{pgfpicture}|, but with the current coordinate transformation matrix synced with the canvas transformation matrix. This command should do the same as if you used || followed by |@hbox|. However, the default implementation of this command will use a ``TeX-translation'' for the translation part of the transformation matrix. This will ensure that hyperlinks ``survive'' at least translations. On the other hand, a driver may choose to revert to a si

} Basically, this should do the same as doing a (scoped) low level sync followed by inserting the box box number directly into the output stream. However, the default implementation uses |@hboxsynced| in conjunction with |@beginpicture| to ensure that, if possible, hyperlinks survive in pdfs. Drivers that are sensitive to picture-in-picture scopes should replace this implementation by codeexample[code only] @beginscope#1@endscope codeexample
