\pgfdata[format=table, read from file=file1.csv]
\pgfdata[format=table, read from file=file2.csv]

% Data is given inline:
\pgfdata[format=table]
{
  x, y
  1, 2
  2, 3
}

# This is some data formatted according to the "coordinates" format
(0,0)
(0.5,0.25)
(1,1)
(1.5,2.25)
(2,4)

description: anchorlabel textnamepath usage command} This command creates a new node. The shape of the node must have been declared previously using ||. The shape is shifted such that the anchor is at the origin. In order to place the shape somewhere else, use the coordinate transformation prior to calling this command. The name is a name for later reference. If no name is given, nothing will be ``saved'' for the node, it will just be drawn. The path usage command is executed for the background and the foreg

anchornamepath usage command} This command is the more general (and less user-friendly) version of the || command. While the || command can only be used for shapes that have a single part (which is the case for most shapes), this command can also be used with multi-part nodes. When this command is called, for each node part of the node you must have set up one -box. Suppose the shape has two parts: The |text| part and the |lower| part. Then, prior to calling ||, you must have set up the boxes ||

coordinate} This command creates a node of shape |coordinate| at the given coordinate. Exactly the same effect can be achieved using first a shift of the coordinate system to coordinate, followed by creating a node of shape |coordinate| named name. However, this command is easier and more natural to use and, more importantly, it is much faster.
existing node} This command does not actually create a new node. Rather, it allows you to subsequently access the node existing node using the name new name.
existing node} This command renames an existing node.

} This command is not a replacement for ||. Rather, when this command is used in a scope, all subsequent node creations in this scope will be affected in the following way: When a node is created, it is not inserted into the current picture. Instead, it is stored in the box ||. Furthermore, the node is not relevant for the picture's bounding box, but a bounding box for the node is computed and stored in the macros || to ||. Then, the macro name is called with the following macros set up: command

The name of the just-created-node. This name will be the originally ``desired'' name of the box plus the fixed prefix |not yet positionedPGFINTERNAL|. The idea is to ensure that the original name is not inadvertently used before the node is actually positioned. When || is called, it will change the name to the original name.

The minimal $x$-position of a bounding box of the node. This bounding box refers to the node when it is positioned with the anchor at the origin. It is guaranteed, that this macro will contain a dimension in the format number|pt|.
This macro stores the path of the background of the node. See Section~section-soft-paths for an overview of how these paths are encode.

} This command is used to position a node that has previously been created using the command ||. When || is called, the macros and boxes mentioned in the description of || must be set to the value they had when the macro name was called. Provided this is the case, this command will insert the box into the current picture, shifted by coordinate. Then, the late code (see below) is called. Subsequently, you can refer to the node with its original name as if it had just been created. codeexample[] =

code} When you call this macro inside a scope for which the || has been called, the code will be stored internally. Later, when the node named node name is actually positioned using ||, the code will be executed. When this macro is called multiple times with the same node name, the code accumulates. However, When || is called, the code stored for the node is cleared. The main purpose of this mechanism is to allow \ to store so-called ``late options'' with a node that will be positioned only late

anchor} This command is another ``point command'' like the commands described in Section~section-points. It returns the coordinate of the given anchor in the given node. The command can be used in commands like ||. codeexample[] pgfpicture 30 rectangle{center}{Hello World!}{x}{stroke} {x{north}}{2pt} {x{south}}{2pt} {x{east}}{2pt} {x{west}}{2pt} {x{north east}}{2pt} fill pgfpicture codeexample In the above example, you may have noticed something curious: The rotation transformation is still in f

point} This command returns the point on the border of the shape that lies on a straight line from the center of the node to point. For complex shapes it is not guaranteed that this point will actually lie on the border, it may be on the border of a ``simplified'' version of the shape. codeexample[] pgfpicture pgfscope 30 rectangle{center}{Hello World!}{x}{stroke} pgfscope {x{2cm{1cm}}}{2pt} {2cm{1cm}}{2pt} {x{-1cm{1cm}}}{2pt} {-1cm{1cm}}{2pt} fill pgfpicture codeexample Remark: If the given poi

shape specification} This command declares a new shape named shape name. The shape name can later be used in commands like ||. The shape specification is some \ code containing calls to special commands that are only defined inside the shape specification (similarly to commands like || that are only available inside the |{tikzpicture}| environment). Here is the code of the |coordinate| shape: codeexample[code only] coordinate { @x=.5 @y=.5 @y by -.5 center{} } codeexample The special commands ar

code} This command declares a saved anchor. The argument command should be a \ macro name like ||. The code will be executed each time || (or ||) is called to create a node of the shape shape name. When the code is executed, the -boxes of the node parts will contain the text labels of the node. Possibly, these box are void. For example, if there is just a |text| part, the node || will be set up when the code is executed. The code can use the width, height, and depth of the box(es) to compute the

code} This command is similar to ||, only instead of setting command to ||$x$|{|$y$|}|, the command is set just to (the value of) $x$. In the |simple rectangle| shape we might use a saved dimension to store the depth of the shape box. codeexample[code only] { @x= } codeexample

code} This command is similar to ||, only at some point in code, command should be defined appropriately, (this could be a value, or some text). In the |regular polygon| shape, a saved macro is used to store the number of sides of the polygon. codeexample[code only] {} codeexample

code} This command declares an anchor named name. Unlike for saved anchors, the code will not be executed each time a node is declared. Rather, the code is only executed when the anchor is specifically requested; either for anchoring the node during its creation or as a position in the shape referenced later on. The name is a quite arbitrary string that is not ``passed down'' to the system level. Thus, names like |south| or |1| or |::| would all be fine. A saved anchor is not automatically also

code} This command declares an anchor named name. It works like ||. However, unlike for anchors declared by ||, name will not be expanded during the shape declaration (i.e.\ not during ||). Rather, the name is expanded when the node is actually used (with || or more likely with ||). This may be useful if the anchor name is context dependent (depending, for example, on the value of a key). codeexample[code only] simple shape{ { } center{} { @x=1cm @y=0cm} anchor {}} tikzpicture [simple shape] (Te

} A border anchor is an anchor point on the border of the shape. What exactly is considered as the ``border'' of the shape depends on the shape. When the user requests a point on the border of the shape using the || command, the code will be executed to discern this point. When the execution of the code starts, the dimensions |@x| and |@y| will have been set to a location $p$ in the shape's coordinate system, and relative to the anchor |center|. Note that || will produce an error if the shape do

} This command specifies the path that ``makes up'' the background of the shape. Note that the shape cannot prescribe what is going to happen with the path: It might be drawn, shaded, filled, or even thrown away. If you want to specify that something should ``always'' happen when this shape is drawn (for example, if the shape is a stop-sign, we always want it to be filled with a red color), you can use commands like ||, explained below. When the code is executed, all saved anchors will be in eff
} This command works like ||, only it is invoked after the text labels have been drawn. This means that this path can possibly obscure (part of) the text labels.

} Unlike the previous two commands, code should not only construct a path, it should also use this path in whatever way is appropriate. For example, the code might fill some area with a uniform color. Whatever the code does, it does it first. This means that any drawing done by code will be even behind the background path. Note that the code is protected with a |{pgfscope}|.
} This command works like ||, only the code is executed after the background path has been used, but before the texts label are drawn.
} The code is executed after the text labels have been drawn, but before the foreground path is used.
} This code is executed at the very end.

|]|} This command allows you to inherit the code for saved anchors from another shape name. The idea is that if you wish to create a new shape that is just a small modification of a another shape, you can recycle the code used for another shape name. The effect of this command is the same as if you had called || and || for each saved anchor or saved dimension declared in another shape name. Thus, it is not possible to ``selectively'' inherit only some saved anchors, you always have to inherit al
|]|} This command can be used to inherit the code used for the drawings behind the background path from another shape name.
|]|} Inherits the background path code from another shape name.
|]|} Inherits the before background path code from another shape name.
|]|} Inherits the behind foreground path code from another shape name.
|]|} Inherits the foreground path code from another shape name.
|]|} Inherits the before foreground path code from another shape name.

|]|name} Inherits the code of one specific anchor named name from another shape name. Thus, unlike saved anchors, which must be inherited collectively, normal anchors can and must be inherited individually.
|]|} Inherits the border anchor code from another shape name.

code:
\anchorborder{%
  % Call a function that computes a border point. Since this
  % function will modify dimensions like \pgf@x, we must move them to
  % other dimensions.
  \@tempdima=\pgf@x
  \@tempdimb=\pgf@y
  \pgfpointborderrectangle{\pgfpoint{\@tempdima}{\@tempdimb}}{\upperrightcorner}
}

description: } Applies the given actions to the current path. Afterwards, the current path is (globally) empty. The following actions are possible: itemize |fill| fills the path. See Section~section-fill for further details. codeexample[] pgfpicture {1cm{1cm}} {1cm{0cm}} fill pgfpicture codeexample |stroke| strokes the path. See Section~section-stroke for further details. codeexample[] pgfpicture {1cm{1cm}} {1cm{0cm}} stroke pgfpicture codeexample |draw| has the same effect as |stroke|. |clip| clips all subs

} This command sets the line width for subsequent strokes (in the current |pgfscope|). The line width is given as a normal \ dimension like |0.4pt| or |1mm|. codeexample[] pgfpicture 1mm {0mm{0mm}} {2cm{0mm}} stroke 2 {0mm{5mm}} {2cm{5mm}} stroke pgfpicture codeexample
Sets the line cap to a butt cap. See Section~section-cap-joins for an explanation of what this is.
Sets the line cap to a round cap. See again Section~section-cap-joins.
Sets the line cap to a square cap. See again Section~section-cap-joins.
Sets the line join to a round join. See again Section~section-cap-joins.
Sets the line join to a bevel join. See again Section~section-cap-joins.
Sets the line join to a miter join. See again Section~section-cap-joins.
} Sets the miter limit to miter limit factor. See again Section~section-cap-joins.

phase} Sets the dashing of a line. The first entry in the list specifies the length of the first solid part of the list. The second entry specifies the length of the following gap. Then comes the length of the second solid part, following by the length of the second gap, and so on. The phase specifies where the first solid part starts relative to the beginning of the line. codeexample[] pgfpicture {0.5cm{0.5cm}{0.1cm}{0.2cm}}{0cm} {0mm{0mm}} {2cm{0mm}} stroke {0.5cm{0.5cm}{0.1cm}{0.2cm}}{0.1cm}

} Sets the color used for stroking lines to color, where color is a \ color like |red| or |black!20!red|. Unlike the || command, the effect of this command lasts till the end of the current |{pgfscope}| and not till the end of the current \ group. The color used for stroking may be different from the color used for filling. However, a || command will always ``immediately override'' any special settings for the stroke and fill colors. In plain , this command will also work, but the problem of def
} Sets both the stroke and fill color. The difference to the normal || command is that the effect lasts till the end of the current |{pgfscope}|, not only till the end of the current \ group.

} This command sets the width of the inner line. Whenever a path is stroked (and only then), it will be stroked normally and, afterward, it is stroked once more with the color set to the inner line color and the line width set to dimension. In case arrow tips are added to a path, the path is first stroked normally, then the inner line is stroked, and then the arrow tip is added. In case the main path is shortened because of the added arrow tip, this shortened path is double stroked, not the orig

} This command sets the color that is to be used when the inner line is stroked. The effect of this command is also local to the current \ group. codeexample[] pgfpicture {1cm{1cm}} {1cm{0cm}} 2pt 1pt red!50 stroke pgfpicture codeexample

} Sets the arrow tip kind used at the start of a (possibly curved) path. The syntax of the start arrow specification is detailed in Section~section-arrow-spec. To ``clear'' the start arrow, say ||. codeexample[preamble={arrows.meta}] pgfpicture Latex[length=10pt] {1cm{0cm}} stroke Computer Modern Rightarrow {0cm{2mm}} {1cm{2mm}} stroke pgfpicture codeexample The effect of this command persists only till the end of the current \ scope.
} Sets the arrow tip kind used at the end of a path. codeexample[preamble={arrows.meta}] pgfpicture Latex[length=10pt] Computer Modern Rightarrow {1cm{0cm}} stroke pgfpicture codeexample

} The argument can be of the form start arrow tip specification|-|end arrow tip specification. In this case, both the start and the end arrow specification are set: codeexample[preamble={arrows.meta}] pgfpicture Latex[length=10pt]->> {1cm{0cm}} stroke pgfpicture codeexample Alternatively, argument can be of the form |[|arrow keys|]|. In this case, the arrow keys will be set for all arrow tips in the current scope, see Section~section-arrow-scopes.

} This command will shortened the start of every stroked path by the given dimension. This shortening is done in addition to automatic shortening done by a start arrow, but it can be used even if no start arrow is given. It is usually better to use the |sep| key with arrow tips. This command is useful if you wish arrows or lines to ``stop shortly before'' a given point. codeexample[preamble={arrows.meta}] pgfpicture {5mm} stroke Latex- 4pt {5mm{0cm}} {2cm{0cm}} stroke pgfpicture codeexample

Dictates that the even-odd rule is used in subsequent fillings in the current \ scope. Thus, for once, the effect of this command does not persist past the current \ scope. codeexample[] pgfpicture {0mm{0cm}}{7mm} {5mm{0cm}}{7mm} fill pgfpicture codeexample

Dictates that the nonzero winding number rule is used in subsequent fillings in the current \ scope. This is the default. codeexample[] pgfpicture {0mm{0cm}}{7mm} {5mm{0cm}}{7mm} fill pgfpicture codeexample
} Sets the color used for filling paths to color. Like the stroke color, the effect lasts only till the next use of ||.

\def\bbgroup{{\ifnum0=`}\fi}
\def\eegroup{\ifnum0=`{\fi}}

% Fails with an error message, but there should be none:
\halign{%
\message{u-part^^J}%
\bbgroup              % <-- in the u-part
\eegroup              % <-- in the u-part
#%
\message{v-part^^J}%
\hfill\cr
\message{body^^J}x
\cr
}

% Fails but should work, the v-part is never reached:
\halign{%
\message{u-part^^J}%
\bbgroup              % <-- in the u-part
#%
\message{v-part^^JJ}%
\eegroup              % <-- in the v-part
\hfill\cr
\message{body^^J}x
\cr
}

}

}
